When and how to use emergency savings

sections.title: The Purpose of Emergency Funds
sections.content: Emergency funds provide peace of mind and financial stability when unexpected expenses arise. They prevent you from going into debt for car repairs, medical bills, or job loss. Having 3-6 months of expenses saved gives you time to handle crises without derailing your long-term financial goals.

points.title: Amount to Save
points.description: 3 months for single-income households, 6 months for variable income or single parents.

points.title: What Qualifies as Emergency
points.description: Job loss, major medical expenses, urgent home/car repairs - not vacations or wants.

points.title: Where to Keep It
points.description: High-yield savings account for liquidity and some growth, separate from checking.

sections.title: Start Small, Build Consistently
sections.content: Even $500 in emergency savings is better than nothing. Build the habit of saving regularly, then increase your savings rate as your income grows.

sections.title: Building Your Fund
sections.content: Start by saving $1,000 for immediate emergencies, then build to 3-6 months of expenses. Use windfalls (tax refunds, bonuses) to boost your fund. Set up automatic transfers from each paycheck to make saving effortless.

sections.title: Build Your Emergency Fund
steps: Calculate your essential monthly expenses (housing, food, utilities, transportation)
Set a savings goal (3-6 months of expenses)
Open a high-yield savings account specifically for emergencies
Set up automatic transfers and track your progress monthly

sections.title: Replenish After Use
sections.content: If you need to use your emergency fund, make replenishing it your top financial priority. Adjust your budget to accelerate savings until it's back to your target level.
